Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Graphene Nanomesh: Band Gap Engineering in Single Layers of Carbon
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: The research program of this CAREER award focuses on a new graphene nanostructure, graphene nanomesh, which can effectively introduce lateral quantum confinement into a large piece of graphene to form a uniform semiconducting nanomesh thin film. Using block copolymer lithography or nanodot lithography, graphene nanomeshes are fabricated with variable periodicities and neck widths down to the sub-5 nm regime, and hence to fine tune the degree of lateral quantum confinement and the size of the band gap. The nanomesh structures are characterized using scanning probe microscopy and transmission electron microscopy. In addition to fundamental materials science research, the project includes electrical transport studies in order to determine the critical material parameters including the band gap and carrier mobility, theoretical calculations carried out through collaborations to understand the fundamental band structure of this new graphene nanostructure and to guide experimental optimization, and fabrication of testing top-gated graphene nanomesh devices.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. The success of the project is expected to have impacts on the further advancement of nanoelectronics and, in general, nanoscience and nanotechnology. The research and education programs of the project are integrated. The research program provides graduate students with an education and training opportunity that is broadly based and goes beyond traditional educational boundaries. Underrepresented groups are actively recruited to participate in the research program. A partnership with industry for education is developed for students to gain first-hand experience in industry and to better prepare them as the future workforce for emerging technologies. The materials and methodologies developed in this project are integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses to broaden the education experience beyond the PI's lab; and are used to train high school teachers and design experimental kits for high school science classes to reach the local communities beyond the university. Together, these efforts contribute significantly to train and supply a steady and diversified source of highly qualified individuals for emerging technologies, and contribute to maintain the competitive advantage of America's technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphene and a wide range of two-dimensional (2D) layered materials are emerging as an interesting class of material due to their unique electronic properties and single-atomic thickness. The central goal of this project is to prepare these atomically thin materials, tune their electronic properties, and explore them for functional electronic and optoelectronic devices. Within the 5 years of the program, we have developed a series of synthetic strategies for the preparation of high quality graphene and other 2D materials, including: the growth of the largest graphene single crystals (at the time), the lateral epitaxial growth atomically thin 2D semiconductor heterojunctions, and a rational co-solvent exfoliation of 2D layered materials; (2) designed novel strategies to tune the electronic properties of graphene nanostructures and investigated their fundamental electrical transport properties, including the first discovery of very large magnetoresistance in graphene nanoribbons; and (3) demonstrated a series of novel device concepts with unprecedented performance, including the creation of the fastest graphene transistors ever, a new concept of vertical transistors, a graphene-plasmonic photodetector, a gate-tunable photovoltaic device based on graphene-MoS2-graphene heterostructures, photodiodes and complementary inverter from epitaxial heterostructures, and the best performed supercapacitors from 3D graphene framework structure. Together, these research accomplishments define an important intellectual underpinning for creating a new material platform for fundamental investigations and totally new technologies at the limit of single atomic layer. It can open up exciting opportunities beyond the reach of the existing materials and impact diverse technological areas, including high speed electronics, ultra-flexible electronics, photodetection, photovoltaics, novel sensors, and energy storage. Our research results have been broadly disseminated through publications in leading scientific journals and also highlighted by a number of scientific media. This research program provides graduate students and postdoctoral fellows with an education and training opportunity that is broadly based and goes beyond traditional educational boundaries. The students were intimately involved in all areas of materials synthesis, device fabrication, and electronic characterization. This interdisciplinary education provided the students with a general appreciation of current challenges and future opportunities in electronics, and a fundamental understanding of the synthesis and processing of nanostructured materials, nanoscale device fabrication and characterization. All this rigorous research training is critical to prepare the students/postdocs to be the next generation of highly qualified scientists/engineers in education and industry. Throughout the program, we have hosted a number of undergraduate researchers, with more than half of which coming from underrepresented groups (female and minority). We have also taken undergraduate and graduate students for field trips to high tech companies for them to gain first-hand experiences in industry and to better prepare them as future workforce for emerging technologies.
